metadata.description: Class 8 Science - Chapter 11: Chemical Effects of Electric Current

question.text: (CBSE 2023) Which of the following is a good conductor of electricity?
question.explanation: Copper sulphate solution is an electrolyte and conducts electricity. Distilled water and sugar solution are poor conductors. Kerosene is an insulator.

question.text: (SEBA 2023) What is the process of depositing a layer of any desired metal on another material by using electricity called?
question.explanation: Electroplating uses electric current to deposit a thin layer of metal (e.g., chromium, gold) on another metal object.

question.text: (CBSE 2022) Which gas is liberated at anode during electrolysis of water?
question.explanation: During electrolysis of acidified water: Oxygen is liberated at anode (+) and hydrogen at cathode (-).

question.text: (SEBA 2022) Which of the following liquids will allow the bulb to glow in a circuit?
question.explanation: All these are electrolytes containing ions that conduct electricity, allowing current to flow and bulb to glow.

question.text: (CBSE 2021) Which metal is electroplated on iron to make cans for storing food?
question.explanation: Tin is non-toxic and prevents iron from rusting. Tin-plated iron is used for food containers (tin cans).

question.text: (SEBA 2021) The decomposition of an electrolyte by passing electric current is called:
question.explanation: Electrolysis is chemical decomposition of electrolyte into its constituents by passing electric current.

question.text: (CBSE 2020) Why is chromium electroplated on objects?
question.option: To prevent corrosion and for shine
question.explanation: Chromium plating gives shiny appearance and protects from corrosion. Used on car parts, bathroom fittings, etc.

question.text: (SEBA 2020) Which electrode is connected to the negative terminal of battery?
question.explanation: Cathode is connected to negative terminal. Anode is positive. Remember: CAThode = Negative (CAT NEGative).

question.text: (CBSE 2019) What happens when electric current is passed through copper sulphate solution using copper electrodes?
question.explanation: In copper sulphate electrolysis with copper electrodes: Copper from solution deposits on cathode. Anode copper dissolves.

question.text: (SEBA 2019) Which of these is a poor conductor of electricity?
question.explanation: Distilled water lacks ions, so it's poor conductor. Adding salt/acid makes it conductive by providing ions.

question.text: (CBSE 2018) Why is zinc coated on iron?
question.explanation: Zinc coating (galvanization) protects iron from rusting even if coating is scratched, as zinc is more reactive.

question.text: (SEBA 2018) Which device is used to detect weak electric current?
question.explanation: LED glows with very small current. Magnetic compass needle deflects even with weak current through wire.

question.text: What are materials that allow electric current to pass through them called?
question.explanation: Conductors allow current flow (metals, electrolytes). Insulators don't (plastic, rubber, dry wood).

question.text: Which process is used to purify copper?
question.explanation: Electrorefining uses electrolysis to obtain pure copper (99.99%) from impure copper for electrical wires.

question.text: What ions are present in acid solutions that make them conductive?
question.explanation: Acids dissociate in water to produce H+ ions which carry current. More H+ ions = stronger acid = better conductivity.

question.text: Why are electrodes usually made of graphite or platinum in electrolysis?
question.explanation: Graphite/platinum are inert electrodes that don't participate in reaction, only conduct electricity.

question.text: What is the electrolyte in electroplating silver?
question.explanation: Silver nitrate (AgNO₃) solution provides Ag+ ions that deposit on cathode during silver electroplating.

question.text: Which metal is used for galvanizing iron?
question.explanation: Galvanization is coating iron/steel with zinc to prevent rusting. Used in pipelines, buckets, car bodies.

question.text: What happens to conductivity when concentration of electrolyte increases?
question.explanation: More concentrated electrolyte = more ions = better conductivity. However, very high concentration may decrease mobility.

question.text: Which gas is produced at cathode during water electrolysis?
question.explanation: At cathode: 2H₂O + 2e⁻ → H₂ + 2OH⁻. Hydrogen gas bubbles form (test with popping sound).

question.text: What is the purpose of adding few drops of acid to water during electrolysis?
question.explanation: Pure water is poor conductor. Adding acid (H₂SO₄) provides H+ ions, making water conductive.

question.text: Which metal is electroplated on steel to make "chrome" parts?
question.explanation: Chromium plating gives shiny, corrosion-resistant surface on car bumpers, taps, bicycle handlebars.

question.text: What happens when electric current is passed through NaCl solution?
question.explanation: Electrolysis of NaCl solution: Chlorine at anode, hydrogen at cathode, NaOH forms in solution.

question.text: Why is copper used for electrical wiring?
question.explanation: Copper has high electrical conductivity, ductility (can be drawn into wires), and doesn't corrode easily.

question.text: What is the chemical effect of electric current?
question.explanation: Chemical effect causes decomposition of electrolyte (electrolysis). Heating effect heats conductor. Magnetic effect creates magnetic field.

question.text: Which metal is used as anode in electrorefining of copper?
question.explanation: In electrorefining: Anode = thick impure copper; Cathode = thin pure copper; Electrolyte = copper sulphate.

question.text: Why do bulbs sometimes not glow even with conducting liquid?
question.explanation: Weak electrolyte produces small current that may not heat filament enough to glow, but can be detected with LED/compass.

question.text: What is the full form of LED?
question.explanation: LED emits light when current passes. More efficient than bulbs, works with very small current.

question.text: Which process prevents iron from rusting by coating with zinc?
question.explanation: Galvanization = zinc coating; Tinning = tin coating; Electroplating = metal deposition using electricity.

question.text: What is the electrolyte in car batteries?
question.explanation: Car batteries use dilute sulphuric acid (H₂SO₄) as electrolyte between lead plates.

question.text: Which metal is used for electroplating jewelry to give golden appearance?
question.explanation: Gold electroplating gives jewelry golden shine at lower cost. Real gold is too expensive for large items.

question.text: What happens to the anode during electroplating?
question.explanation: Anode metal dissolves into electrolyte, replacing metal ions that deposit on cathode. Anode loses weight.

question.text: Why is plastic coating used on electrical wires?
question.explanation: Plastic/rubber insulation prevents electric shock and short circuits by not allowing current to leak.

question.text: Which industrial process uses electrolysis of NaCl solution?
question.explanation: Chlor-alkali process produces chlorine, hydrogen and sodium hydroxide from brine (NaCl solution).

question.text: What is the role of battery in electroplating?
question.explanation: Battery provides direct current (DC) for electroplating. AC would deposit and remove metal alternately.
